tutorial.title: Style a Blog with Flexbox
tutorial.descriptionContent: Learn how to use Flexbox to Style a blog

executableContent.instructions:
You'll be improving the layout of a website that covers JavaScript news about updates, new projects, and other important matters. 

Take a look at the starter code. Everything you'll work with is at the top of the sheet.

Run the code and look at what we're starting with. Think about some issues with the page you'll need to address. You'll use your Flexbox skills to address these issues.

We'll first set a minimum and maximum width for the body. Also, the heading is not part of a Flexbox container and needs to be centered.

1. Set the maximum width to `800px` for the `body` element.
2. Set the minimum width to `600px` for the `body` element.
3. Align the text of the `h1` element in the `.heading` class so that its centered.

files.name: style.css

executableContent.instructions:
The first container we need to address is the one for navigation. Currently, the elements appear compacted and hard to read.

You'll need to position the elements using Flexbox. The content will appear as ordered in the HTML. The links and the image need to be positioned on opposite sides of the page.

1. In the class for the navigation container; set the `display` for flexbox.
2. Code the property and value for the default direction of the flex content.
3. Justify the content so the elements are flush on the edges of the page.

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
Make sure to code the `display` property in the `.navContainer` class selector.

Make sure to code the `flex-direction` property in the `.navContainer` class selector.

Make sure and code the `justify-content` property in the `.navContainer` class selector.

executableContent.instructions:
The navigation looks better, but the links aren't well aligned vertically. Also, the image of the earth now on the far right side of the page needs a little margin.

1. Align the navigation links and the image on the cross-axis in the navigation container.
2. In the ID `#navPhoto`, set the property for the right margin to `10px`.

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
Make sure that the `align-items` property is in the `.navContainer` class selector.

Make sure that the `margin-right` property is in the `#navPhoto` ID selector.

executableContent.instructions:
The navigation is almost there! The anchor tags need some styling to match the mockup.

1. Give the links `10px` of margin to space them away from each other.
2. Code the color for the text of the links to be `#36454F` or `rgb(54, 69, 79)`. These values are the same.
3. Set the property for `text-decoration` to `none` to remove the underline.

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Make sure that the `margin`, `color`, and `text-decoration` properties are in the `a` selector.

executableContent.instructions:
The navigation is done! Let's move on to the headlines. The headlines also need to be positioned with flexbox. The direction of the items will again be a row, starting from the right side of the page. 

We'll also need to enable flex-wrap to handle horizontal overflow from the flex container.

1. Turn the container for the headlines into one of type Flexbox.
2. Set the `flex-direction` property to start the row on the right side of the page.
3. Make the container wrap.

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Make sure that the `display`, `flex-direction`, and `flex-wrap` properties are in the `.headlineContainer` class selector.

executableContent.instructions:
We need to move the headline titles inline with the images. We also need to center the text for a better appearance.

1. In the `.headlineImage` class, float the element to the left to remove it from the normal flow.
2. Align the `h3` elements to the center of the space they occupy.

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
Make sure that the `float` property is in the `.headlineImage` class selector.

Make sure that the `text-align` property is in the `headlineItem h3` descendant selector.

executableContent.instructions:
The headlines are almost done. The individual headlines need to be arranged vertically and horizontally to give them a more refined look. 

1. Justify the content for the `.headlineContainer` class to the center of the page.
2. Use the correct flexbox property and value to evenly distribute the items along the cross axis.

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
Remember that the `justify-content` and `align-content` properties must be in the container where we add `flex` display property. 

You can use `space-around` as the value of `align-content` to evenly distribute the items along the cross axis.

executableContent.instructions:
The headlines are finished! We'll now move to the column container. We'll need enough space for all of the items to be arranged vertically. 

If we set a height that's too large, it'll leave empty space on the page. We want to give the items room to allow responsiveness but eliminate extra space. A maximum height works well here.

1. Set the maximum height of the column container to `250px`. You may not see a change but this is allows the column to extend it's height if necessary.

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Make sure that the `max-height` property is in the `.column` class selector.

executableContent.instructions:
The column items need to be arranged with Flexbox. They also need to be justified so that they have even space between them.

1. Turn the elements of class `.column` to display using Flexbox.
2. Default Flexbox causes the items to appear in a row. Set the direction of the Flexbox to be a column.

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Make sure that the `display`, `flex-direction`, and `justify-content` properties are in the `.column` class selector.

executableContent.instructions:
Finally, we need to align the items on the cross axis. We also need to center the text of the items in the columns, for a cleaner look.

1. In the column container, use the correct Flexbox property to center the items on the horizontal axis.
2. In the `.colItem` class code the `text-align` property and center it.

Make sure that the `align-items` property is in the `.column` class selector.

Make sure that the `text-align` property is in the `.colItem` class selector.

executableContent.instructions: And that's all! You've successfully used your Flexbox skills to match the mockup for the webpage using multiple Flexbox containers. There are no tests here, so feel free to experiment with the code and see what changes you can add.
